data.title: Beware of the Car! (1966)
data.meta_description: An insurance agent who moonlights as a carthief steals cars various crooks and never from the common people. He sells the stolen cars and gives the money to charity. His best friend, a cop, is assigned to bring in this modern robin hood.
data.text:
"Anyone without a car dreams of buying one. And anyone who’s got a car dreams of selling it, but doesn’t do it just because once it’s sold, you are left without a car. A human being, more than any other living creature, likes to create himself as many problems as possible. That’s the only reason to wish to have a car of your own. The idea of leaving 5 and a half thousand just like that in the street can poison even the happiest life."

Women Film Editors #71: Yekaterina Ovsyannikova

Ah, a true treasure! Much like the earlier Soviet feature Jolly Fellows, the sweet satire in Beware of the Car (or, as I had previously seen the title translated,…

Spoliers ahead.

A gentle crime film from Eldar Ryazanov, the Russian master of romantic comedy, Beware of the Car is a love story alright, but it's one more akin to the director's brilliant Ballad of a Hussar, made two years earlier, than it is his best known works, Office Romance and The Irony of Fate, or Enjoy Your Bath. This is because, while the latter two films are melancholy, heterosexual romances, the former is a love story about a man and a woman who he thinks is a man; Beware of the Car goes one step further, simply embracing the love between two men in the kindest, most gentle way possible.

Yuri Detochkin (Innokenty Smoktunovsky) is an insurance salesman and…

Everyone's favourite timeless detective comedy (not vice versa), in which the director Eldar Ryazanov represented his greatest ideas and, most significantly, showed us a diverse range of actors in roles that partly were unconventional for them. My favourite cool story about this film is how Ryazanov barely persuaded Innokentiy Smoktunovskiy to play Yuri Detochkin. Initially, Yuri Nikulin was invited to play this character (he declined), as well as Oleg Efremov (he eventually earned the second main role), and Leonid Kuravlev (the commission didn't like him). They didn't, however, show a childish spontaneity or a sense that they were slightly out of this world, which were key features for Detochkin's character.
